message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest the most likely diagnosis is primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). ERCP is the gold standard for diagnosing PSC as it can identify the characteristic findings of multifocal strictures and ductal irregularities. Contrast CT and ultrasound may show hepatosplenomegaly, but not the characteristic ductal changes seen in PSC. MRCP may show ductal changes, but it is not as sensitive as ERCP.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and past medical history suggest the most likely diagnosis is primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). ERCP is the most accurate test to diagnose PSC. The other options may show findings consistent with PSC, but are less specific than ERCP.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of pruritus, jaundice, and hepatosplenomegaly, along with the history of ulcerative colitis, suggest primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). ERCP is the gold standard for diagnosing PSC, as it allows direct observation of the bile ducts and obtainment of tissue samples for histology. Contrast CT and ultrasound can only suggest the diagnosis of PSC, while MRCP may be useful for visualization but cannot provide tissue samples.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a liver problem, while the past medical history of ulcerative colitis may indicate primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), a possible complication. ERCP is considered the most accurate test for the diagnosis of PSC. Contrast CT and ultrasound can also show hepatosplenomegaly, but are less specific. MRCP is used for evaluating biliary and pancreatic ducts, and may not be as useful in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pruritus and jaundice with hepatosplenomegaly suggest cholestasis, which can be caused by primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) in patients with ulcerative colitis. ERCP is the gold standard for diagnosing PSC. Contrast CT and ultrasound can show hepatosplenomegaly but cannot confirm the diagnosis of PSC. MRCP can show biliary tract abnormalities but is not as sensitive as ERCP in diagnosing PSC.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of pruritus, jaundice, and hepatosplenomegaly suggests cholangiocarcinoma or primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) with an increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma. ERCP is the most definitive investigation to diagnose and confirm cholangiocarcinoma or PSC. Contrast CT and ultrasound may show dilated bile ducts but cannot make a definitive diagnosis. MRCP can also be used to diagnose biliary tree disorders, but ERCP is more invasive and can also provide therapeutic options such as stent placement.

The presentation of pruritus, jaundice, and hepatosplenomegaly suggests cholestasis, which can be caused by primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) in patients with ulcerative colitis. ERCP is the gold standard for diagnosing PSC. Contrast CT and ultrasound may show cholestasis but cannot diagnose PSC. MRCP can diagnose PSC but is not as definitive as ERCP.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and past medical history suggest primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). ERCP is the most appropriate diagnostic test for PSC.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation suggests a possible hepatobiliary disorder. ERCP is the most accurate test in diagnosing primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). MRCP is less invasive but less accurate. Ultrasound and contrast CT may help identify hepatosplenomegaly but are not specific for PSC.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has pruritus and jaundice, as well as hepatosplenomegaly, which are suggestive of cholangiocarcinoma. Cholangiocarcinoma can often be diagnosed with ERCP, which allows for visualization and biopsy of the biliary system. The other options may also be helpful in diagnosing the cause of the patient's symptoms, but ERCP is the most specific for cholangiocarcinoma.
